utterances: Yeah, Fugees is short for refugees, yes.
Let's get to the work of Yele Haiti.
Your website describes the organization as more than just an NGO.
What do you mean by that?
So, I say, well, we'll use the same approach that we used in New York in the '80s, when break dancing, graffiti, and music was the tool that was used to go inside of these communities.
And it has been working.
So, the food is being distributed by local hip-hop musicians who deliver the food.
To clean up the streets, we developed a hip-hop competition where whoever writes the best rap about cleaning up the streets we produce a thousand CDs for them that they can sell back themselves.
And we put them on a local television station.
So we have like hundreds and hundreds of programs like this which boost up the self-esteem of the children.
And that's what Yele is about.
Let's go to a caller.
Guy in Cleveland, Ohio, would like to speak to you.
Guy, what's on your mind?
Hello?
Hello.
Hi.
Hi.
What's your thought?
Hi.
Hey, Wyclef, (speaking in foreign language)?
(Speaking in foreign language), how are you?
I'm from--I'm calling from Cleveland.
It's ironic, man.
We're related but we've never met.
I'm related to every Haitian in the world.
I should--let me translate.
(Spoken in foreign language).
Yes.
Anyway, to make a long story short, I just wanted to say that, well, I'm related to the Gypsy Sea(ph) part of the family.
OK.
Anyway, to make a long story short, I just wanted to congratulate you for what you're doing.

You're my idol and, you know, what you're doing is really something that I think if other Haitians were as--I mean, there's a lot of Haitians in this country but they're not really as patriotic as you are.
And I tip my hat to you for that.
And I wanted to know specifically what you're doing in Haiti.
OK, Guy.
Thank you so much for joining us.
Thank you, cousin.
The specifics of Haiti basically is programs with focuses on education, health, the environment, and culture.
So we're going inside the communities and we're using music as the tool for development to set up a lot of programs like that.
So far we have given scholarships to children.
We have rebuilt schools.
And we have a distribution--a food distribution program that we do every two weeks.
How is it, Wyclef Jean, how is it that you are able to get into some of these communities when the other NGOs have not?
I mean, you've been able to get food into neighborhoods where there's been so much fighting that other people haven't been able to do it.
How do you do it?
I mean, my music is the tool.
I mean, you have to--I'm going inside of these neighborhoods where these kids have been listening to my music for over 12 years.
Do you mean that your fame precedes you and that's why?
Or are you saying something else?
No, because it's beyond the fame.
See, I have two CDs.
Every time I always do an English CD, I always do music in Creole, too, which registers in their language and then their struggle.
So it's beyond fame.
It's more like they feel that I am them and I am part of them.
Let's go to Jacksonville.
Let's go to Shantel(ph) in Jacksonville, Florida.
Shantel, what's on your mind?
Hi.
How are you?
I'm from Jamaica.
And I was wondering how is it--you've kind of answered my question but how is it that you manage because it's such, like, a strong political tension right now?
How do you manage to, you know, do so much charity work, you know, like channel your charity work, do that, although there is so much political tension going on?
Shantel, thank you.
Well, it's the same way that Snoop can go into his territory and do what he does.
Dr. Dre can go into his neighborhood.
It's the same way Wyclef can go into his neighborhood.
We have no political agenda.
The music speaks for itself.
And the lyrics are something that the people can identify with.
So it allows us to be able to go in and do our work because the people really feel that it's work that's being done that's non-political.
You know, sometimes there's a sense that, forgive me for using the word celebrity, but you are a celebrity, that sometimes celebrity-philanthropy can be short-lived.
And how do you maintain trust in your organization?
How do you assure the people that this is not a short-time commitment, that you will be there?
How are you able to do that?
Well, people have been following me since 1996 when I first put the Haitians flag on my back and have driven the flag from 1996 through the year that we're in, 2006.

So the people that have been following yearly Haiti or my movement in Haiti, they know that this is something that is just a movement of the heart, like the brother who got on the phone to tell you I'm real patriotic when it comes to where I come from.
So this just might be a new movement in the sense of it's getting more light now.
But this is like years and years of hard work.
And the people who follow it, the core audience knows exactly what's going on.
Do you ever find it disorienting to have come from the kind of poverty you talked about earlier and now to live in the kind of affluence that you now enjoy?
No, because for me, all men and women, you know, I mean, the philosophy that my parents brought me up on is that we all are kings and queens.
And when you grow up in situations, the whole idea is to rise.
And as you rise, help people rise.
So that's what I believe in.
As the way that you see I'm living today, this is the way that it was meant for man to live, period.
So I don't really believe that because you're from like a poor neighborhood that you're going to be poor the rest of your life.
I think let me be an inspiration, that kid that ate dirt.
Come on, boys, out this way.
How do you get Americans to share your vision for Haiti?
I mean, as we discussed at the beginning of the program that many Americans only experience Haiti through the statistics, through the worst.
How do you get them to share your vision of change, the changes possible?
Through my music, you know?
Like Americans love Wyclef Jean, through the music.

And I've been able to take people like Angelina Jolie, Brad Pitt, Jimmy Henchman, a lot of different people, to the island of Haiti and have shown them why I'm so patriotic and I feel like this is the best place in the Caribbean.
Okay.
Let's to go Fort Wayne, Indiana and Jason.
Jason, what's on your mind?
Hi.
I just wanted to commend you for your work.
And, you know, in 1997, I was in Haiti with a medical relief mission.
And I just, I fell in love with the people and the culture and the language.

And one of the things that I noticed there, and I think you were right to touch on it, that the United States and other areas, you know, we look down on Haiti because there seems to be a lack of motivation with the political prophets that's there.
And I was wondering what your thoughts were as far as how this might revitalize?

While it's not a government organization, you know, how is this going to, you know, revitalize and turn the people of Haiti, you know, back on to politics and put trust back into the political process?
Well, I think that politics -- that's a good question.
I think politics will always be there, you know?
I think like in any country I think the issue of corruption will always be there.
But I feel that there's ways that you can raise money through technology and different ways that's going on right now to actually show people that a change can happen.
I don't necessarily think that anybody's going to trust giving money to, you know, political situations in Haiti right now.
But as Yele Haiti, I could just speak on behalf of what we're doing.
